main event: On 15 October 1958 in Olympic National Park, Washington, a ground-visual observation was made of a round, orange-red object, which brightened and dimmed, appearing to be twice the size of neighboring stars. The investigation indicated the possibility of the object being the star Capella, visible during the time of observation and in the same quadrant.
interesting points: The observation lasted for a stationary period with the object still visible
The object was described as round, orange-red, and appeared to brighten and dim, making it stand out from neighboring stars
The report suggests the possibility of the object being a star, Capella, visible in the same quadrant during the time of observation
The location of the observer was in Olympic National Park, Washington
The observer was identified as a 37-year-old electric welder from Bremerton, Washington
sighted object: round, orange-red object in the sky
